description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Det Sida-finansierade Somalia Resilience Programmet (SOMREP) syftar till att stödja sårbara pastorala och jordbrukshushåll i landsbygdsområdena samt i urbana områden i Somalia. SOMREP implementeras av ett konsortium bestående av 7 internationella organisationer och bildades i respons till torkan 2011 i hopp om att förhindra framtida katastrofer. I samband med klimatförändring, fattigdom och den sköra politiska och säkerhetsmiljön i Somalia är det kritiskt att ha tillräckliga hanteringsmekanismer för att motstå återkommande chocker och katastrofer såsom torka och konflikter. Programmet syftar till att göra det möjligt för hushållen att anpassa, absorbera och omvandla dessa chocker till något hanterbart. SOMREP-insatser hjälper till att utrusta hushållen med passande verktyg, resurser och kompetenser för att öka deras hushållsproduktivitet. Några av insatserna inkluderar resurshantering, tidiga varningssystem, affärsutveckling, försörjningsstöd, djurhållning, jordbruk, kontantöverföringar och andra säkerhetsnät och resiliensbyggandeinsatser.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The Sida-funded Somalia Resilience Programme (SOMREP) aims to support vulnerable pastoral and farming households in the rural and peri-urban areas of Somalia. SOMREP is implemented by a consortium of 7 international agencies and was established in response to the 2011 drought in hopes to prevent future disasters. In the context of climatic variability, poverty and the fragile political and security environment in Somalia, it is critical to have the adequate coping mechanisms to withstand recurring shocks and disasters such as drought and conflicts. The programme aims to enable households to adapt, absorb and transform these shocks into something manageble. SOMREP interventions help equip the targeted households with with the proper tools, resources and competencies to increase their household productivity. Some of the interventions include resource management, early warning systems, business development, livelihood support, animal husbandry, farming, cash-transfers and other safety-nets and resiliene building efforts.

The objective of the programme is to: increase the resilience of chronically vulnerable people (disaggregated by Age, Gender & Diversity - AGD), HHs, communities and systems in targeted pastoral, agro-pastoral and peri-urban livelihood zones SomReP proposes to allocate funding for Phase 2 for the next three years from 2018 - 2021 according to 5 Outcome areas: - Outcome 1: Enhanced risk management and disaster preparedness through community action and contingency planning in Somaliland and Puntland - Outcome 2: Enhanced food security and capacity to meet social needs through sustainable cash-based assistance mechanisms and improved access to social capital -Outcome 3: Enhanced livelihood diversification for women, men, and youth through the restoration and protection of productive assets, value chains and the uptake and adoption of agricultural technology - Outcome 4: Enhanced management and governance of natural resources, including soil and water systems to support sustainable pastoral livelihoods - Outcome 5: Program learning and research generated and shared among relevant stakeholders (including communities, NGOs, and government)

description.narrative:
Key results in this reporting period include:
1. In responding to COVID-19, the balance of USD 44,050/SEK 474,474.66 from the drought response activities was utilized to pilot the surprise soap project for children between 5-12 years and development of videos and other messaging on COVID-19 to create awareness. SomReP supported the government to develop a protocol to enable the rapid development and dissemination of informational material to be distributed through a wide network of government, NGO and UN networks to raise awareness, provide practical guidance, and combat false information. These efforts greatly contributed to preventive measures to contain the spread of COVID-19 that contributed to economic challenges as price increments affected food availability as well as outreach efforts to communities for trainings. The efforts enabled a gradual de-escalation of movement restrictions and influenced adaptive actions to support continued delivery of resilience interventions but also trade as markets re-opened.
2. Following the completion of the Gender Sensitive Climate Vulnerability and Capacity Assessment (GCVCA) and community sensitization in year 1, communities were supported to develop and implement contingency plans. The plans entail equipping the communities with skills on data collection techniques to get the required information for community disaster management and contingency planning.
3. Significant progress was made where a total of 3350 households were reached with cash for work (CFW) interventions geared towards improving community assets to withstand and recover from recurring shocks. A total of USD 127,920 was distributed through the CFW activities. These interventions contributed to an increase in the percentage of people with little or no hunger by 49% as reported by the Annual Resilience Measurement (ARM) due to increased savings from the cash intervention in the year 2020.
4. 40 water structures were rehabilitated in year 2, it is estimated that these water points will provide water to an estimated 43,975 households across the project. To ensure proper management of the water points, 115 participants were trained on water management. 29 Natural Resource Management (NRM) committees were also established and a total of 9 Farmer Managed Natural Regeneration (FMNR) sites were established to effectively manage water and agricultural land resources. The NRM committee members were trained on conflict resolution to build their capacity to address potential conflicts related to natural resource management and administration.
5. Most Technical Unit (TU) meetings such as the Donor Advisory Groups, Technical Working Group and Quarterly Review meetings were held virtually due to the COVID-19 pandemic, however the project still ensured business continuity where possible. The project undertook the Annual Resilience Measurement process in partnership with government line ministries, the team ensured that the ARM covered relevant project locations for assessment to assess annual progress. The joint analysis approach is highly commendable and in line with strengthening the collaborative approach required for multisectoral and multiactor support in resilience building.
